Howdy Folks,

While I typically use dynamic invocation and TestSuite(s)
to define (and therefore invoke) my JUnit tests, I was under
the impression from both the JUnit JavaDoc and from memory
(as faulty as that can be... <sigh>) that setUp() and tearDown()
are called using both approaches.

However a question came up recently that if you specify the
tests by overriding the runTest() method as below (static
invocation), that setUp() and tearDown() do not get called
for every method, but only get called once.

protected void setUp()
{
    System.out.println("setUp()");
}

protected void tearDown()
{
    System.out.println("tearDown()");
}

public static void main(String[] args)
{
    TestCase tc = new MyTest("Testing runTest()")
    {
       public void runTest()
       {
           //--- These just print their name like setUp().
           testDoOneThing();
           testDoSomethingElse();
       }
    };
    tc.run();
}

The output from this test was:
setUp()
testDoOneThing()
testDoSomethingElse()
tearDown()

1) Am I doing something so obviously wrong that I cannot see it?
    (This is always possible! <G>)

2) Do both static and dynamic invocation call setUp()/tearDown
    before/after each test?

3) Is it because I am not going through a TestRunner? If so, how
    would I modify the example to specify which tests, and then
    invoke the TestRunner? By using TestSuite.addTest("testName")?

4) Is there a way to get this behavior using static invocation?

Just looking for a clear view on this.
-- 
Thanks,
